title: Landover, Maryland
text:
Landover is an <a href="unincorporated%20area">unincorporated community</a> and <a href="census-designated%20place">census-designated place</a> in <a href="Prince%20George%27s%20County%2C%20Maryland">Prince George's County</a>, <a href="Maryland">Maryland</a>, <a href="United%20States">United States</a>. As of the <a href="2010%20United%20States%20Census">2010 census</a> it had a population of 23,078.
Landover is contained between Sheriff Road and Central Avenue to the south, Hill Road, Cabin Branch Drive, and the <a href="Washington%20Metropolitan%20Area%20Transit%20Authority">Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority</a> (Metro) Orange Line tracks to the west, John Hanson Highway (<a href="U.S.%20Route%2050%20in%20Maryland">U.S. Highway 50</a>) to the north, and Washington D.C.'s Capital Beltway (Interstate 495/95) to the east. Landover borders the communities of <a href="New%20Carrollton%2C%20Maryland">New Carrollton</a>, <a href="Landover%20Hills%2C%20Maryland">Landover Hills</a>, <a href="Glenarden%2C%20Maryland">Glenarden</a>, <a href="Lanham%2C%20Maryland">Lanham</a>, <a href="Ardmore%2C%20Maryland">Ardmore</a>, <a href="Kentland%2C%20Maryland">Kentland</a>, <a href="Cheverly%2C%20Maryland">Cheverly</a>, Chapel Oaks, <a href="Fairmount%20Heights%2C%20Maryland">Fairmount Heights</a>, <a href="Carmody%20Hills%2C%20Maryland">Carmody Hills</a>, <a href="Peppermill%20Village%2C%20Maryland">Pepper Mill Village</a>, <a href="Walker%20Mill%2C%20Maryland">Walker Mill</a>, and <a href="Largo%2C%20Maryland">Largo</a>
History.
Landover was named after the town of <a href="Llandovery">Llandovery</a>, Wales.
The former CDPs of Landover, <a href="Dodge%20Park%2C%20Maryland">Dodge Park</a>, <a href="Kentland%2C%20Maryland">Kentland</a>, and <a href="Palmer%20Park%2C%20Maryland">Palmer Park</a>, defined as such by the <a href="U.S.%20Census%20Bureau">U.S. Census Bureau</a> in the <a href="1990%20U.S.%20Census">1990 U.S. Census</a>, were consolidated into the <a href="Greater%20Landover">Greater Landover</a> CDP as of the <a href="2000%20U.S.%20Census">2000 U.S. Census</a>. This amalgamated area was renamed the Landover CDP as of the <a href="2010%20U.S.%20Census">2010 U.S. Census</a>.
Geography.
Landover is located at . According to the <a href="United%20States%20Census%20Bureau">U.S. Census Bureau</a>, it has an area of , of which , or 0.13%, is water. Landover residents have the postal zipcode of 20785. Since Landover is an unincorporated community in Prince George's County, residents of Landover have Hyattsville postal addresses though they live in Landover and not Hyattsville. Landover does not have its own postal zipcode.
Landover consists of several small subdivisions which are notably Ardwick Park, Kentland, Kenmoor, Dodge Park, Brightseat, Palmer Park, Columbia Park, Village Green, White House Heights, and Summerfield. Landover has been home to the Fedex Field Stadium, which the NFL's <a href="Washington%20Football%20Team">Washington Football Team</a> have played at since it opened in 1997. It is also home to the Prince George's Sports & Learning Complex, WMATA's Landover Metrobus Division, WMATA's Carmen E. Turner Maintenance Facility, Giant Food Corporate Office, Giant Food Corporate Plant, National Harmony Memorial Park Cemetery, and Ardwick Industrial Park. WMATA <a href="Washington%20Metro">Metrorail</a>'s <a href="Orange%20Line%20%28Washington%20Metro%29">Orange Line</a> from New Carrollton to Vienna, MARC train Line to the BWI Light Rail Station to Washington D.C.'s Union Station, Cargo Trains, and Amtrak's Train Line from Washington D.C.'s Union Station to New York's Penn Station via Wilmington and <a href="Philadelphia">Philadelphia</a>, all go through Landover. <a href="Landover%20Hills%2C%20Maryland">Landover Hills</a> is a separate, incorporated community just across the Orange Line train tracks and John Hanson Highway (U.S. Highway 50) to the north. Landover is the birthplace of the late <a href="Len%20Bias">Len Bias</a>. From 1960 to 1972, Landover was the home of jazz guitarist, composer, arranger, author, and jazz educator <a href="Steve%20Rochinski">Steve Rochinski</a>.
For the <a href="2000%20United%20States%20Census">2000 census</a>, Landover was delineated by the U.S. Census Bureau as the <a href="Greater%20Landover%2C%20Maryland">Greater Landover</a> census-designated place.
Economy.
Eight O'Clock Coffee's coffee production plant is located in Landover. <a href="Giant-Landover">Giant Food</a> has its headquarters in a location in <a href="unincorporated%20area">unincorporated</a> Prince George's County in the Ardwick Industrial Park area, near Landover. The Giant Food Headquarters is located next to the New Carrollton Metro Station. It is served by the F13 metrobus shuttle that goes from the Cheverly Metro station to Washington Business Park.
Arts and culture.
<a href="Beall%27s%20Pleasure">Beall's Pleasure</a> and <a href="Ridgley%20Methodist%20Episcopal%20Church">Ridgley Methodist Episcopal Church</a> are listed on the <a href="National%20Register%20of%20Historic%20Places">National Register of Historic Places</a>. A Harlem Renaissance Festival occurs at Kentland-Columbia Park Community Center in Landover every year in May. In 2014, the <a href="National%20Archives%20for%20Black%20Women%27s%20History">National Archives for Black Women's History</a> was controversially relocated from <a href="Washington%2C%20D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a>, to 3300 Hubbard Road in Landover.
Sports.
<a href="FedExField">FedExField</a> is a <a href="American%20football">football</a> <a href="stadium">stadium</a> for the <a href="Washington%20Football%20Team">Washington Football Team</a> of the <a href="National%20Football%20League">National Football League</a> in the neighboring CDP of <a href="Summerfield%2C%20Maryland">Summerfield</a> and has a Landover postal address. (See also <a href="Raljon%2C%20Maryland">Raljon, Maryland</a>.) The <a href="Washington%20Wizards">Washington Wizards</a> and <a href="Washington%20Capitals">Washington Capitals</a> used to play in Landover's <a href="US%20Airways%20Arena%20%28Washington%2C%20D.C.%29">US Airways Arena</a> (Formerly known as the Capital Centre) before moving to the <a href="Capital%20One%20Arena">Capital One Arena</a>, inside D.C itself. The arena was demolished in 2002.
The Prince George's Sports & Learning Complex is also in Summerfield CDP, located on approximately adjacent to FedExField.
Government.
<a href="Prince%20George%27s%20County%20Police%20Department">Prince George's County Police Department</a> headquarters, which is also District 3 Station, is in the <a href="Palmer%20Park%2C%20Maryland">Palmer Park</a> area in Landover CDP.
The <a href="U.S.%20Postal%20Service">U.S. Postal Service</a> operates the Landover Post Office in the CDP.
Education.
Public education.
Landover is a part of the <a href="Prince%20George%27s%20County%20Public%20Schools">Prince George's County Public Schools</a> system.
Elementary schools serving sections of the Landover CDP include: Columbia Park, Dodge Park, Cooper Lane, Gladys Noon Spellman, Highland Park, and William Paca. Middle schools serving sections of the Landover CDP include: G. James Gholson, Kenmoor, and Charles Carroll. Senior high schools serving sections of the Landover CDP include: <a href="Fairmont%20Heights%20High%20School">Fairmont Heights</a>, <a href="Charles%20Herbert%20Flowers%20High%20School">Charles Herbert Flowers</a>, <a href="DuVal%20High%20School">DuVal</a>, and <a href="Bladensburg%20High%20School">Bladensburg</a>. The schools serving the 1990 CDP are: Cooper Lane and Gladys Noon Spellman elementaries, Charles Carroll Middle, and Bladensburg High.
When <a href="desegregation%20busing">desegregation busing</a> began in 1972, PG County school officials bused many black children in Landover to schools with large numbers of white students in other areas of the county. Since then many schools in the Landover area had closed. David Nakamura of the "<a href="Washington%20Post">Washington Post</a>" stated that many Landover residents believed that desegregation busing contributed to the socioeconomic decline of Landover. In 1998 the busing program was abolished due to a settlement in federal court.
Matthew Henson Elementary School was previously in the CDP. It was scheduled to close in 2009. In 2012 EXCEL Academy agreed to open a charter school in the former Henson space, and it moved from its previous campus in Riverdale.
Other area schools:
Colleges and universities.
Landover had career-based colleges, such as Fortis College, that offer programs including bio-technician, medical assisting, and medical coding and billing.
Infrastructure.
Transportation.
Landover is one of the few regions in the Washington, D.C. area that is served directly by two separate Washington Metro rail lines. Landover is served by both the <a href="Orange%20Line%20%28Washington%20Metro%29">Orange</a> and <a href="Blue%20Line%20%28Washington%20Metro%29">Blue</a> lines (many DC area suburbs are not served directly by Metrorail at all). The <a href="Landover%20%28WMATA%20station%29">Landover</a> <a href="Washington%20Metro">Washington Metro</a> station serves the northern portion of Landover on the Orange Line. The Landover Metro Station is also the primary metro station that serves the Landover area. The <a href="Morgan%20Boulevard%20%28WMATA%20station%29">Morgan Boulevard</a> Metro station, constructed in 2004, serves the southern portion of Landover on the Blue Line and is the main rail terminus providing access to <a href="FedExField">FedExField</a>, which is home to the <a href="Washington%20Football%20Team">Washington Football Team</a> in addition to many other sporting and entertainment events. Landover also has a special Metrobus Division also houses many metrobuses that serve routes in Prince George's County, Maryland.
In addition to the Landover and Morgan Boulevard Metro Stations that primarily serve the Landover area, Landover residents have access to other metro stations nearby, such as the New Carrollton Metro Station, Cheverly Metro Station, Largo Town Center Metro Station, and Addison Road-Seat Pleasant Metro Station.
I-495/95, the <a href="Interstate%20495%20%28Capital%20Beltway%29">Capital Beltway</a>, crosses <a href="U.S.%20Route%2050%20in%20Maryland">U.S. Route 50</a> in Landover. The Beltway also has junctions with <a href="Maryland%20Route%20202">Maryland Route 202</a> (Landover Road) and Brightseat Road, which leads directly to FedExField.
Shopping.
Landover was the home of <a href="Landover%20Mall">Landover Mall</a>, owned and operated by <a href="Lerner%20Enterprises">Lerner Enterprises</a>. Built in 1972, it was the first enclosed mall in the <a href="Washington%2C%20D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a> metropolitan area to house four high-end retail anchor stores: Garfinkel's, <a href="Hecht%27s">Hecht's</a> (owned by the May company), <a href="Woodward%20and%20Lothrop">Woodward and Lothrop</a> (popularly known as Woodies), and <a href="Sears">Sears</a>. The mall also housed a multiplex movie theater located in the basement of the northeast corridor of the building. Located at the Capital Beltway and Landover Road, the mall neighbored the towns of <a href="Palmer%20Park%2C%20Maryland">Palmer Park</a>, <a href="Ardmore%2C%20Maryland">Ardmore</a>, <a href="Glenarden%2C%20Maryland">Glenarden</a>, and <a href="Largo%2C%20Maryland">Largo</a>. Palmer Park was the hometown of Olympic boxing champion <a href="Sugar%20Ray%20Leonard">Sugar Ray Leonard</a>. Garfinkel's closed in 1990, Woodies closed in 1995 and was replaced with a <a href="J.C.%20Penney">J.C. Penney</a> store that lasted from 1996 to 2001, and Hecht's closed in 2002 with the opening of the <a href="Bowie%20Town%20Center">Bowie Town Center</a> located in <a href="Bowie%2C%20Maryland">Bowie</a>. The entire mall officially closed in 2003 and was demolished in 2006, with the exception of Sears. Sears closed in 2014 and was later demolished.
With the arrival in 1997 of <a href="FedExField">FedExField</a>, the mall's parking lot is used for overflow parking. In 2007, according to the "Washington Post", Prince George's County officials were in the midst of developing plans to transform the area where Landover Mall once stood. County officials propose to build luxury townhouses, trendy stores, and office buildings. The goal of the project is to transform the area into a residential and cultural hub that replicates the <a href="Bowie%20Town%20Center">Bowie Town Center</a>, and <a href="The%20Boulevard%20at%20the%20Capital%20Centre">The Boulevard at the Capital Centre</a>; the latter is in <a href="Lake%20Arbor%2C%20Maryland">Lake Arbor CDP</a> and has a Largo postal address. Woodmore Towne Centre, featuring <a href="Costco">Costco</a> and <a href="Wegmans">Wegmans</a>, opened in 2010 in nearby <a href="Glenarden%2C%20Maryland">Glenarden</a>.
Parks and recreation.
The Prince George's County Department of Parks and Recreation operates the Kentland Community Center and the Palmer Park Community Center.
